”.

If that is the case you should have one or more team members with function “Sales Document Approval- Level 3” in the team maintained via app “Manage Teams and Responsibilities” and should add a new step / task in the workflow with condition “CMR > 10000 USD” with recipient / role “Sales Document Approval - Level 3”.

entry.title: Re: Error in the configuration of Hire template
entry.content: Hello @gabrielasz, I do not remember exactly what I did, but in order for the fields to be editable everything is managed through the RBP permissions. Try setting the permission for “Employee Central Effective Dated Entities” → “Personal Information” to Edit/Insert, or configure the field permissions for “Employee Data – Hire Date”, “Employee Data – Company”, and “Employee Data – Event Reasons” (the ones you use) as Edit/Insert.

entry.title: Re: LMS Admin Users and assigning learning activities
entry.content:
Hi,

Here are a few points of note:

The items need to be on a security domain separate from other items if you do not want the admin to be able to assign other courses.

The permission for the admin needs to include a security domain group that includes that specific domain. There is a possibility of having multiple security domain groups for a specific role, the group is used to break down the specific permissions of a role.

I think to fully help you would require further discussion on what you have currently, which parts are not working for you, and ultimately where you want to be. Please feel free to reach out directly if you would like to discuss further.

Heather

entry.title: Re: How to get available stock for production order in EW...
entry.content:
When you release a PP01 production order, ATP checks stock at the IM (Inventory Management) level, typically at the plant or storage location. However, EWM operates at a warehouse-level granularity, and it considers:

  • Bin-level availability
  • Reservations already made for other orders
  • Stock in transit or blocked
  • Control cycles and PSA (Production Supply Area) assignments

So even if ATP says “yes, stock is available,” EWM might say “nope, or already reserved.”

Follow the below steps to avoid this situation

  • Configure ATP to check MRP areas that reflect EWM-managed locations. This gives a more accurate picture of what's truly available.
  • In customizing (OPJJ), activate storage location inspection for your checking rule. This forces ATP to check availability at the storage location level, not just plant level.
  • Ensure your control cycles correctly link the PSA to the EWM-managed storage bin. If this link is broken or misconfigured, staging fails.
  • Use reservation strategies that prioritize staging for released orders. You can also implement logic to prevent over-reservation across multiple orders.

entry.title: Re: CR 2025 Filters selection not working
entry.content:
According to CR's supported platform for databases, Express versions are not supported:


Crystal Reports 2025 – Data Sources
Please consult the xlsx file CR2025 Data Access
Notes
• Crystal Reports is offered as a 64-bit native binary. It requires 64-bit data source middleware connectivity on all operating systems.
• Crystal Reports uses the 64-bit ODBC registry on all versions of Windows. To administer 64-bit ODBC DSNs on 64-bit versions of Windows, run the 64-bit ODBC
Administrator, located here: %windir%\System32\odbcad32.exe
 
Possibly one of these DB Clients may work though:
ODBC  Microsoft ODBC Driver 17 for SQL Server
OLEDB  Microsoft OLEDB Driver 18 for SQL Server
JDBC Microsoft JDBC Driver 8.2 for SQL Server
ODBC DataDirect ODBC (10)

It also depends on how the date field is defined, if they don't show up then CR can't determine the type being used.

entry.title: Re: Is B.sc degree enough for ABAP career
entry.content:
In case you don't want to study anymore - it's really up to you and I don't think anyone saying the opposite will change your mind based on your question.

However I suggest to talk with people you work with. Not that people here could not help but this is a technology forum not a career advice forum. It's not so easy for most people to tell negative points of any SAP career INSIDE an official SAP website (I personally could not care less)

Still, in case you want to use some social media for that - go to reddit (<irony>or maybe the most relevant social media according to SAP, Bluesky</irony>). There are a lot of similar debates there around SAP career advices and people are very active on these threads.

entry.title: Re: Is B.sc degree enough for ABAP career
entry.content:
Yes a Professional Master degree is good but I recommend to concentrate on the below SAP technical side since you already have 2+ years

  • SAP Fiori/UI5: Front-end development for modern SAP apps
  • SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform): Cloud-based extensions and integrations
  • SAP CDS Views & RAP Model: For building scalable, cloud-ready applications
  • SAP Functional Modules: Like SD, MM, or FI if they want to pivot toward techno-functional roles

“ABAP is a strong foundation, but SAP is evolving fast; learning Fiori or RAP can make you future-proof.”

Also to stay tuned with the latest updates,

access this SCN forum as much as possible
SAP Learning Hub 
openSAP for free courses

These platforms offer continuous learning, networking, and access to experts.

entry.title: Re: Best Approach for Deleting a Company and All Its Data...
entry.content:
Hi @ValdevyPires 

Thank you for your question.

Regarding the request to delete a company code and all related data in SAP. It is important to note that deletion is generally not recommended or supported once the company code has transactional data across modules.

Here are some key points you should note:

Deleting a company code can cause data inconsistencies and legal/audit issues since financial and tax data must be retained for years. It may disrupt reporting, intercompany transactions, and external integrations.

Best practices include blocking the company code for further postings, closing and reconciling balances, and using SAP archiving solutions to manage historical data.

Data migration or system simplification can also be considered.

Physical deletion is possible only if no transactional data exists and is typically limited to pre-go-live scenarios.

Specialized third-party tools exist for complex data carve-outs but should be used with caution.

My recommendation is, instead of deletion, advise the customer to block and archive the company code, keeping the system compliant and consistent. For restructuring or simplification, involve SAP’s Data Management & Landscape Transformation team for a selective carve out or consolidation project.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

SAP Note 1820315 Data Archiving

entry.title: Re: Actual costing run leading ledger (4-4-5) and non lea...
entry.content:
Hi @kasireddych 

To run Actual Costing once for your main ledger with a 4-4-5 fiscal calendar and again for the India Stat ledger with an Apr-March calendar, the typical approach is for you to:

First, make sure you enable inventory valuation for both ledgers with their respective fiscal calendars.

Then you can run Actual Costing separately for each ledger considering its fiscal calendar period close. CKMLCP allows selection of ledger and period, so you can execute it once for your main ledger’s 4-4-5 month close and then again for the India Stat ledger’s calendar month close.

Please note that inn S/4HANA, material ledger supports multi-ledger parallel valuation allowing flexibility for different calendar periods. Many Indian companies using S/4HANA with Actual Costing run separate valuation and settlement for their India Stat books aligned with the statutory calendar, while maintaining the 4-4-5 calendar for corporate reporting.

Finally, do ensure careful configuration of fiscal year variants, ledger assignments, and inventory valuation settings in IMG and material ledger.

I hope this provides more insights. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Guide for migrating PI/PO B2B mappings to Integration Suite B2B TPM
entry.content:
There are a few steps you need to take before you can use the Figaf tool to migrate the B2B scenarios. You need to setup an environment that will enable you to process the EDI setup.

Migrating B2B from PI to Integration Suite will be a demanding task, that will take you some time to get familiar with. But with this guide, you will learn how to complete a migration to having an operational B2B scenario in the Integration Suite, which can be validated and regression tested.

The task here is performed using Figaf tool, but they can also be performed manually though expect that it will take much longer time. 

Notice this has been recorded on a preview of Figaf 2508, so if you are using older versions, there may be small differences.

Note, naming conventions: The naming conventions are essential for handling this in a larger perspective.   There is a purpose for using all settings as specified in the videos.

Before you can get started with the migration, you should install Figaf in your own environment and configure it. The best guide is this one.

You will be taken through the following procedural steps:

– Prepare Company, no video for this, since this is a basis one-time task

– Prepare Partner Profiles, using the Figaf fast-track

– Prepare MIGs, and ideally MAGs

– Prepare Integration Suite TPM Agreement Templates, using naming conventions

– Perform migration of PI/PO Operation mapping to Integration Suite TPM  

Create company

You should have created your self as a company and if required, the subsidiaries you will be using. I would recommend you check how Figaf creates the Partner profiles and add Identifiers and Systems in the same way.

Video Guide 1: Create B2B Partner Profiles

See how the Figaf B2B “PI to CPI migration” menu’s fast-track feature “Create Partner Profiles“, will help you to quickly prepare all the partner profiles with corresponding systems and identifiers, for your PI B2B migrations.

Video Guide 2: Creation of MIGs and MAGs 

As apart of the preparation for your PI B2B migration, you will need to define all MIGs, and ideally also MAGs, so that you can proceed to the preparation of agreement templates.

When migrating a B2B solution from PI, you will not be needing the MAG, but having them in place, even as empty mappings, will ensure that your Agreement Templates are better aligned using correct MIGs. Preparing MAGs (complete or not) is not required for the migration process, but advisable.  

Video Guide 3: B2B Agreement templates

How to prepare the mandatory B2B Agreement Templates for your full B2B scope of message formats (typeSystems).

Video Guide 4: B2B Migration

Now you are ready to perform the migration using Figaf’s “PI to CPI Migration” menu.

In this video you can see how to perform the migration, and how to re-use your PI test cases for the newly created agreement.

You will also see, how the B2B scenarios are easier to manage and monitor in the Figaf “B2B” menu.

entry.title: How to Specify SAP DMS Repository for Different Projects in SAP Build Process Automation?
entry.content:
Hi Community,

We’ve integrated SAP Document Management Service (DMS) with SAP Build Process Automation (BPA) by creating a destination in our BTP subaccount. After this setup, BPA forms started showing the option to upload documents, and the files are getting stored in DMS.

In our destination configuration, we specified a repository ID, and all uploaded documents are automatically saved in that specific repository. BPA is even organizing the documents by creating a dedicated folder for each form submission, which is great.

However, here’s the challenge:

We have multiple projects in BPA within the same subaccount, and we’d like to use different repositories for different projects. But currently, I don’t see any way in BPA to specify or override the repository per project or per form.

Is there a way to specify the DMS repository that a particular BPA project or process should use for file uploads?
If not directly in BPA, is there any workaround or recommendation?

Any insights or best practices would be appreciated!

entry.title: ‌🇧🇷‌ Virtual: 6th ASUG BR Meeting - SIG Localization
entry.content:
ASUG Brasil invites its members to the 6th ASUG BR Meeting – SIG Localization, a focused online session dedicated to key developments and challenges in the Brazilian localization landscape. 

Agenda Highlights:

  1. NF Serviço Eletrônica: O que esperar para 2026?
    A forward-looking discussion on the evolution of electronic service invoicing in Brazil and what companies should anticipate in the coming year.

  2. Reforma Tributária – Contingência para 2026
    Insights into the upcoming tax reform and strategic considerations for contingency planning.

  3. Troca de Experiência
    An open exchange session for participants to share experiences, challenges, and best practices related to localization in SAP environments.

This session will be conducted in Portuguese and is designed to support SAP professionals in Brazil navigating regulatory changes and localization requirements.

Registration link

entry.title: Creating Custom 'Document Definition' as part of 'Document and Reporting Compliance' process of SAP
entry.content:
Hello all, 

With this Blog post I would like to share my latest experience working with 'Document and Reporting Compliance' component of SAP, which is used for generating Statutory Reports and SAP has already shipped Country-specific compliant Report Templates (pdf template is what we are going to cover as part of this post) as part of this feature/framework/component, still there might be some scenarios where we would need some Custom Changes to be incorporated into the SAP shipped Document Definitions and a similar case am going to elaborate here in which we made some changes in the pdf format Document of the Italian Fixed Asset Register(IT_FXDAST_REG) Report Definition by copying the same to a Custom Version and thereby applying the needed changes as per customer requirement.

Apart from pdf below are the other Document Formats supported (here mainly we would be discussing pdf Document type)

Helpful links:

  • This link talks about the whole 'Statutory Reporting component (this link could be skipped and the subsequent document could be referred if one is already acquainted with the 'Statutory Reporting process of SAP'). Statutory Reporting
  • Our main focus as part of this post would be 'Defining Custom Statutory Reports by referring the SAP Shipped Report Definition (it's recommended to go through the document before proceeding ahead in order to understand the various sub-components involved like Parameter Definition, Query Definition , Document Definition , Schema, PDF Form Template etc. and how all these components are inter-linked). Define Statutory Reports  

Scope of this post:

  • 'Define Statutory Reports' section as part of Setting up the Statutory Reporting process would be covered which is done using a Fiori app with same name. Custom Development is required at this part of the process only which would be the main topic to be covered as part of this post.
  • SPRO Configurations required for Setting up the 'Run Compliance Reports' won't be covered as part of this post. Above mentioned helpful links and the already shipped Configurations should help in understanding and setting up the same.

Recommended having prior knowledge of:

  • XML Interface based AdobeForm building.
  • Little Knowledge of XML based .xsd Schema files.

Requirement: Requirement was to make some changes (adding some fields at Header and Item level) in the pdf format Document of the Italian Fixed Asset Register(IT_FXDAST_REG) Report Definition by copying the same to a Custom Version and thereby applying the needed changes as per the customer requirement.

Details of the steps involved:

Step 1 : Copy standard Report Definition 'IT_FXDAST_REG' to a Custom one say 'YY_TEST_IT_FXDAST_REG'

This step will copy all the below mentioned 7 components of the Report Definition, out of these 3rd and 4th i.e. Query Definition and Document Definition respectively are the most important one for carrying out the Custom Changes.

i.) Properties

ii.) Parameter Definition

iii.) Query Definition

iv.) Document Definition

v.) Correspondence Definition

vi) Event Handler

vii.) Reported Items Log

Understanding the Parameter Definition, Query Definition and Document Definition components above briefly. Recommended to go through the document Creating a Report Definition

a.) Parameter Definition : This step defines the Input Parameters and its properties for a Report e.g. what and all should be the Input Parameters like Company Code , Asset Class etc. and the properties of these Input Parameters like Optional, Hidden, Read-Only etc. In-short its the same as defining the Selection Screen in ABAP ALV Report. Values for these Parameters are set during the Setting up of 'Run Compliance Reports' procedure.

Note: Activate this before proceeding to the next step else you won't be able to use these properly in the subsequent steps. In most cases you won't need to make any changes here. 

b.) Query Definition : As part of a Report  Document/Output there would be various Entities (like Header fields , Item columns , Footer fields etc.) which we would need to get filled or populated with respective data, using Query Definition option you can define the various Re-usable queries which can be used to map with the various entities of the final Report Document/Output.

Below is the overview of various Queries available as part of Report Definition 'IT_FXDAST_REG' , 

Note: Here, we have added one Custom Query and also we have Changed the Source of an Existing Query. 

Note: A Query can be defined with any of the below listed Data Source types:

c.) Document Definition : It's in this step where we would define or say structure the layout of the legal Report documents that should get generated during the Statutory Reporting process. While creating the document definition, you can also assign an existing schema, or create a new schema for the document. It is at this step where we map various entities/nodes of the final legal Report document with the Re-useable queries we defined in the previous step. Documents of Type XML, TXT, ALV, JSON, PDF and XBRL can be defined as part of this step. As part of this post we would be focusing mainly on the pdf Document Type.

Step 2 : Working with the Query Definition.

Here, we will define a new Query with Data Source Type as 'Database Table' and also we will customize an existing Query-Class based Query by attaching a Z Custom Class to it as Data Source.

a.) Creating a Custom Query with Data Source of type 'Database Tables'

Select Data Source Type as 'Database Tables/Views' from the drop down and provide the Table name in the Data Source Name field.

Scroll down and in the Filters section set the filters, Note: Here, Set the Filter as per the mapping cardinality(this is part of the next step that is Document Definition mapping). Suppose, if the cardinality is 1:1 that means only one record is expected to be fetched and returned by this query hence, the Filter parameter should also be passed accordingly, such that it returns only one record.

Here, for the field ANLKL (Asset Class) of Table ANKA we are setting the Filter criteria by passing value from the output of another Existing Query called FILE_SPLIT.

So this is just like below SELECT SINGLE query,

SELECT SINGLE * FROM anka WHERE anlkl EQ file_split-assetclass

b.) Customizing existing Query-Class based Query 'TOTAL_ASST_CLSS'  by attaching a Z Custom Class to it as Data Source.

Here, we copied the Standard Query Class CL_FIAAIT_REG_DATA to Z_TEST_CL_FIAAIT_REG_DATA and will make Changes in the Method 'GET_PDF_TOTAL_ASST_CLSS' which is indeed responsible for filling data into this Query that is 'TOTAL_ASST_CLSS'. What we did is added a Custom field in the Output Structure and filled some dummy value as shown below,

Set the Parameters same as it was before for this Query, note Whenever you change the Data Source Type of a Query its Paramters need to be set again.

Finally Select all the Queries and Activate them, Note: Until and unless all the Queries are activated you wont be able to use them in subsequent steps.

Step 3 : Working with the Document Definition.

Note: Refer the Standard pdf Report Document 'IT_FXDAST_REGISTER_PDF' shipped as part of Report Definition 'IT_FXDAST_REG' in parallel for understanding how various parameters need to be set while configuring this part.

Finally it's in this step where we would define or say structure the layout of the legal Report documents that should get generated during the Statutory Reporting process and map all the output elements with the Queries we created above in the previous step.

a.) Click on Add option and select 'Add with Schema/Query' from the drop-down and provide the Document ID ( e.g. here it is 'YYIT_FXDAST_REGISTER_PDF' ) and set Document Type as 'PDF'

Now, here we need to maintain the Schema, which is the most important part of Report Definition. Schema is the metadata or say skeleton of the Data Service which would be use in this case for providing the Interface/Context/Data to the AdobeForm which we would indeed used for Binding the output elements in AdobeForm Layout.

Note: Here we need to define a new Schema and hence Schema ID reason being we are going to add some Custom Fields which is not part of the Standard SAP Shipped Schema and Document.

If you check the Standard pdf Report Document 'IT_FXDAST_REGISTER_PDF' shipped as part of Report Definition 'IT_FXDAST_REG' the Schema ID attached there is 'IT_FXDAST_REG_7'. Download/Export this Schema and we will enhance this Schema to accommodate the Custom Fields we want to add to the pdf Output. A .xsd extension XML file would be download.

Now using any of the XML editing tool you are comfortable with like Notepad++ edit this .xsd Schema file to add the Custom fields:

We added Type declaration as well in the bottom,

So, as a summary we have added fields like below, i.e. added 2 Custom fields(CUSTOM_FIELD1_ERDAT and CUSTOM_FIELD2_AEDAT ) in the Top level flat Structure and this would be filled by the new Database Table based Query we created and also in the existing Nested Structure 'ASSET_CLASS_TOTALS' we have added a Custom field inside that and for deriving the value of that field we have changed the Class~Method based Query  'TOTAL_ASST_CLSS' as demonstrated in the previous step by creating a Custom Query Class. These things would get more clear once we step into the mapping part.

b.) Continuing ahead with Defining the PDF Document process, provide the below values,

Here, the main thing is Schema ID , generate a new Schema (like here I have generated with Schema ID YIT_FXDAST_REG_1) using the Schema .xsd file we created in the previous step. Secondly, attach a Form Template so here I have copied the SAP shipped AdobeForm 'IT_FXDAST_REG' to a Custom one 'YY_TEST_IT_FXDAST_REG' and attached the same here. Do create a Custom Interface as well by copying the existing one, here it would be a XML Based Interface and the Form would be a Fragment based Form.

Note: Remaining other settings keep the same as it was with the SAP Standard one.

c.) Continuing ahead with mapping part,

Once, the Schema ID is generated and Uploaded, all the Entities/Fields which were in the .xsd Schema would start appearing in the Mapping tab. Now, here we need to map each of these fields with the Queries.

Note: We need to map the newly added 3 fields properly with the Query we added and changed, remaining other fields need to be mapped as it was in the Standard. We need to keep in mind that whenever a new Schema is uploaded all the Existing mapping gets wiped off and we need to map again.

Here for field CUSTOM_FIELD1_ERDAT we Selected Data Source as 'Query Column' and Corresponding Value part we will set using the F4 help, which will indeed show all the Queries we defined previously,

So, here we selected Corresponding Value as YY_TEST_IT_FXDAST_REG_CUST_HDR Query's ERDAT field i.e. Y_TEST_IT_FXDAST_REG_CUST_HDR-ERDAT . Do, the same for the remaining 2 fields as well.

Very Important:

1.) If any of your Query is not Active in the Query Definition Step then the F4 here won't work, hence make sure the the Query Definition part is fully Active.

2.) For the remaining Existing Fields refer the Existing Document definition and set all other parameters same like that for example Loop Query, Data Source, Corresponding Value if all these values are not set properly in the mapping then the Nested Structures and Flat structure elements won't work properly and Output won't be rendered correctly.

Step 4 : Making changes into the XML based AdobeForm Interface,

Open the XML based AdobeForm Interface say in this case YY_TEST_IT_FXDAST_REG which was created by copying Standard SFP Interface IT_FXDAST_REG. Load the same .xsd Schema file using which we created the Schema in previous step.

Activate the Interface

Step 5 : Making changes in the AdobeForm layout.

Bind the newly added fields into the AdobeForm Output Elements, 

Activate.

With this we are done with the Document Definition part and now we can configure the Run Report and generate the Reports.

Output: 

Pointers helpful for an analyzing a execution:

1.) Run Program 'SRF_GENERATE' in SE38 for analysis a Report Execution,

Provide Report Definition and the Report Run UUID,

For getting the Report Run UUID either press F4 there or use Table SRF_REP_RUN , pass REPORT_RUN_ID from the 'Run Compliance Report' Fiori app,

2.) Some of the Statutory Reporting Framework related Codes which could be helpful while debugging and analysing:

a.) FM SRF_GENERATE_DOCUMENT , PERFORM generate_document > search for “DATA(lo_pdf_document) = NEW cl_srf_pdf_generator( )."

b.) CL_ SRF_GENERATOR~ PROCESS_ELEMENT_WO_ITERATION 

c.) CL_SRF_REPORT~RETRIEVE

Thanks,

Sijin

entry.title: Datasphere: Using Inherited Standard Variables in Derive Value Variables
entry.content:
Hello,

I have an Analytic Model (B) built on top of another Analytic Model (A) with a standard variable for CALWEEK being inherited. It's a bit strange to me that this is not allowed. Is it not possible to use inherited standard variables as mappings in other variables?

Regards,

Dimitar

entry.title: Re: I want to change the background color when there is n...
entry.content:
I believe you can achieve the desired result using threshold with an extra trick.

Threshold can be used to color cells in a table based on the cell value w/o showing the value itself. This cannot directly be used on NULL cells. But if you define a calculation that converts NULL to a numeric values which is very unlikely to appear, then this can be used to define a threshold coloring the background of the cell.

I was using the following steps for a Universal Measure Model:

  1. Add a calcuated member to the structure dimension using this formula: IF(ISNULL( [#Measure Values]) ,999999999999 ,[#Measure Values]
  2. Ensure the structure dimension is assigned to the free axis (not assigned to an axis) and filtered to this new member
  3. Define a threshold for neutral range and values between >= 999999999999 < 1000000000000
  4. Customize the color used for this threshold
  5. apply table styling for threshold style=Color Background without Values

I see one issue with this trick: The hard coded value does not have a unit. The original table showed the same unit in every cell and thus could extract the common unit to the table title. This is no longer possible with the hard coded value that does not have a unit.

entry.title: Re: Open Vendor Confirming Items in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
As per this SAP Help the mass migration of accounts payable open items with the special G/L indicator referring to the special G/L type 'W' must be posted manually in financial accounting. This also means, SAP does not support automated migration of open items involving Special G/L type W via tools like:

  • SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit
  • BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_POST
  • Direct staging table uploads

To handle this correctly, follow this two-step workaround:

Use the migration cockpit or staging tables to migrate the vendor invoice only (without the CME payment). Leave the payment portion out of the automated migration.

After migration, manually post the Special G/L payment using FB01 or F-53 with the appropriate Special G/L indicator. This ensures the payment is correctly linked and reflected in the system. If you're dealing with a large volume of such items, consider using batch input sessions to automate FB01 entries

entry.title: Re: Smartforms barcode with barcode content embedded as i...
entry.content: To print a barcode in a Purchase Order PDF Smartform in SAP, first select the desired barcode type (e.g., Code 128) and ensure the corresponding font is installed on the SAP system. Access the Smartforms transaction (SMARTFORMS) to create or modify the relevant Smartform. Add a text element where the barcode will appear, format the barcode value (e.g., using concatenation to include start and stop characters), and set the font to the installed barcode font. Adjust the layout as needed, then save and activate the Smartform.

entry.title: Re: Verification of Payee (VoP) - What is planned in SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP
entry.content:
@dvid 

1. We have no general FAQ, but we could create one. 

2. Order type derivation in S/4 is done via configuration. That needs to be done by each customer. Within Multi-Bank Connectivity only the response order type (for pain.002) has to be registered (I linked the description how to open a service request) witihin the text). 

3. With Bank Portal we refer to online banking.  

4. Regarding pulling, I would not expect that it is necesarry to change your cycle. 5-10 seconds is the defined reaction time between PSPs, there is no definition how fast you need to react on the verification result. You could even authorize/reject days later.

entry.title: Re: Story report calculating average years of service- calculator delivering inaccurate information
entry.content: just a small suggestion for creating stories, it's always a good idea to add a table and see the data per person in a cross-tab. You can have your people and their tenure and this might give you an insight what's wrong there. It can be duplication of rows (same person appears several times or something else). You need to debug it on a person level and not the total measure level

entry.title: Converting Group Financial Data to separate Chart of Accounts
entry.content:
Hi there,

We have a requirement to transform consolidated financial data into a separate chart of accounts that is native to a companies holding company (Outside of SAP). The financial data/balances will need to be reported at the G/L level of their CoA. Since we are leveraging the YCOA of operational postings in the spirit of fit to standard methodology, we came up with the following solutions:

  • Explode the FS item registry to be 1 to 1 relationship with YCOA. Likely making the FS item imitating the YCOA. Then leverage FS Item Hierarchy to display the FS item balances in the holding companies CoA, using different nodes. Is there a concern with exploding the FS item registry, as standard typically follows the most granular line item of the financial statement. However global hierarchies can do this for us as well. 
  • Leverage "Group Account Number" from the G/L Account Master Data to maintain the holding companies CoA. Then export financial data using "Group Data Analysis" to report the group account number as a dimension. This solution seems logical, but my concern is the future state of this field. Is there a chance this field gets deprecated in the future? My other concern, is that when exporting financial statement item data, through "Group Data Analysis", the system losses visibility at the YCOA level when crossing over fiscal years. For example, when a balance carry forward is complete, all "account number" details from previous fiscal years is summarized as "#", see below:
    •  

    •  

       

       

Happy to hear other suggestions. Your thoughts are welcomed!

entry.title: Integrating SAP Process Orchestration into an Event-Driven Architecture with SAP Advanced Event Mesh
entry.content:
As organizations accelerate their digital transformation, event-driven architecture (EDA) has emerged as a powerful approach for building scalable, real-time, and loosely coupled systems. Solutions like SAP Advanced Event Mesh serve as enterprise-grade event brokers that support asynchronous messaging patterns across hybrid and cloud-native landscapes.

On the other end of the spectrum lies SAP Process Orchestration - a robust, time-tested middleware platform still running mission-critical integrations in many enterprises. While SAP has officially announced the end-of-life of SAP Process Orchestration, with long-term support ending in the coming years, replacing it entirely is often a long, phased journey.

This blog post is not about extending the life of SAP Process Orchestration indefinitely, but rather about integrating it into your modern architecture—bridging the gap between legacy and modern systems. By connecting SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Advanced Event Mesh via JMS with JNDI, you can start to decouple systems and adopt EDA principles without a complete rip-and-replace.

We assume you're familiar with setting up scenarios in Process Orchestration, so we’ll skip over iFlow configuration and focus instead on:

  • Deploying Solace JMS libraries in SAP Process Orchestration
  • Configuring SAP Advanced Event Mesh for JNDI (Java Naming and Directory Interface) support
  • Setting up the JMS receiver channel in Process Orchestration to connect to Advanced Event Mesh

This approach provides a low-friction way to modernize the edge of your SAP Process Orchestration integrations while planning for long-term migration. It enables you to offload responsibilities to the event broker, reduce point-to-point connections, and pave the way for loosely coupled microservices or SAP Integration Suite adoption. Let’s dive in.

Use Case

Our integration scenario is as follows:

  1. REST Sender Adapter receives a message from Postman or any REST client to reliably test the setup.
  2. Process Orchestration routes the message to a JMS Receiver Adapter.
  3. The JMS Receiver connects to Advanced Event Mesh via JNDI, and publishes the message to a target queue.

Prerequisites

  • SAP Process Orchestration 7.5 or newer (Java-only stack preferred)
  • Access to SAP Advanced Event Mesh
  • Admin access to the Advanced Event Mesh Broker Manager for configuration
  • SAP NetWeaver Administrator access to deploy shared libraries

Step 1: Download the Solace JMS Library

As with most integration scenarios with Advanced Event Mesh our first starting point is the Connect tab of your Cluster Manager. We are interested in using the Solace JMS API which uses the Solace Message Format (SMF) as a protocol and can find all the information we need there:

 

  • Go to Get Started to find further documentations of the API and more importantly downloads for the sol-jms library.
  • When choosing a version for the sol-jms library it is crucial to understand any required dependencies. Feel free to familiarize yourself with the Solace provided API documentation regarding supported Java environments and dependencies.
    https://docs.solace.com/API/Solace-JMS-API/JMS-API-supported-environments.htm
  • For this blog I decided to go with a JMS 1.1 implementation which makes sol-jms-10.19.0 a good choice to keep dependencies to a minimum since as of version 10.20, the Solace Messaging API for JMS has a dependency on JMS 2.0 and would require a compatibility layer.
  • Using this version, the only dependencies needed in my case were
    • Apache Commons Logging (This blog uses commons-logging-1.1.3)
    • A implementation of the JMS 1.1 specification for messaging in Java applications (This blog uses geronimo-jms_1.1_spec-1.1.1)
  • Feel free to experiment with different versions or even a JMS 2.0 implementation, but make sure to include dependencies accordingly!

Step 2: Deploy Solace JMS Library in SAP Process Orchestration

Generally the activity of deploying external drivers such as JMS libraries into the Java stack of SAP Process Orchestration is done by Basis, so as a developer you might not necessarily have the required access and/or knowledge to perform this. The following is just an outline of the process. For more guidance refer to the following blog:
How to Deploy External JMS and JDBC drivers in SAP PO 7.5

  • Package the relevant JAR files you identified in the previous section (sol-jms and dependencies) into a Software Deployment Archive (SDA). You will either need to add the JAR files to the currently deployed SDA of your Process Orchestration or deploy a new one from scratch.
  • After creating your SDA deploy it to the Java stack. This can be done for example using SAP NetWeaver Developer Studio (NWDS) and requires administrator access.
  • After successful deployment you should be able to find your resources in the Java Class Loader:

Step 3: Configure JNDI in SAP Advanced Event Mesh

To facilitate establishing the JMS connection between SAP Process Orchestration and SAP Advanced Event Mesh in the easiest way possible we are going to make use of JNDI. While it is most certainly possible to setup a generic JMS Receiver in Process Orchestration without JNDI it will not be covered in this blog. Instead head to your Advanced Event Mesh Console to:

  1. Enable JNDI Access
    • Select your Broker in the Cluster Manager and open the corresponding Broker Manager.
    • Navigate to Messaging > JMS JNDI.
    • Enable JNDI if not yet enabled under JNDI Settings and create a JNDI Connection Factory.
      • In this example I chose /JNDI/TEST for the Connection Factory
      • The rest of the Connection Factory settings are left at default, but feel free to adjust transport properties as necessary.
  2. Define the Queue
    • Go to Messaging > Queues.
    • Create a Queue
      • In this case I called it T28_JMS according to the ID of my SAP Process Orchestration system, adjust as necessary
      • Ensure is enabled and properly permissioned.
  3. Bind Queue and Connection Factory to JNDI
    • Under JMS JNDI > Queues, create a new JMS Queue
      • The JNDI Name defines how we are going to address this queue from Process Orchestration. I chose is /JNDI/T28_JMS to keep naming consistent with the..
      • Physical Name, where you select the actual queue you just created in Advanced Event Mesh

Step 4: Configure JMS Receiver Channel in SAP Process Orchestration

Here’s the setup of the JMS Receiver Adapter:

Parameters:

  • Adapter Type: JMS
  • Transport Protocol: Access JMS Provider with JNDI
  • Message Protocol: JMS 1.x

Connection Parameters:

  • Name of JNDI Initial Context Factory:
    com.solacesystems.jndi.SolJNDIInitialContextFactory is the initial Context Factory provided by the sol-jms library
  • JNDI Lookup Name of Topic/QueueConnectionFactory & JMS Queue/Topic:
    This is what we just created in the Advanced Event Mesh, in my case /JNDI/TEST and /JNDI/T28_JMS
  • JNDI Server Address,  Logon User & Password:
    You can find the Server Address and credentials for the default user solace-cloud-client under the Connect tab in the Cluster Manager of your AEM broker where we got the sol-jms library in the beginning. Be sure to include the Message VPN in the JNDI Logon User with an '@' symbol.
  • The solace-cloud-client user should only be used for development purposes. Be sure to create a proper client via Broker Manager > Access Control in your Advanced Event Mesh for productive use.

After configuring your JMS Receiver Adapter make sure the other parts of this scenario are ready as well and activate them.

Step 5: Test via the REST API platform of your choice

  1. Send a test payload to your REST endpoint. In my case I will send a very basic XML message.


  2. The scenario processes and routes the message to the JMS Receiver channel.


  3. The Message will get published to the queue specified in Advanced Event Mesh. You can monitor this by checking in the Broker Manager > Queues that your queue is receiving messages.

Troubleshooting Tips

  • ClassNotFoundException: Ensure the sol-jms library and dependencies are correctly deployed.
  • JNDI Lookup Failures: Confirm the JNDI names in Process Orchestration match exactly with those configured in Advanced Event Mesh.
  • Security Errors: Check that the user has appropriate permissions in the Advanced Event Mesh broker.

Conclusion

Connecting SAP Process Orchestration with SAP Advanced Event Mesh using JMS and JNDI offers a powerful way to bridge synchronous process-driven integrations with event-driven systems. With Solace’s sol-jms library and proper JNDI configuration, you can seamlessly push data to Advanced Event Mesh queues and unlock real-time integration patterns across your landscape.

While this blog focused on configuring JMS and JNDI for queue-based messaging, which is ideal for point-to-point delivery and tightly scoped integrations, it’s worth noting that a topic-based architecture may be better aligned with future-facing, event-driven designs. Topics enable a publish-subscribe model, allowing multiple systems to consume the same event independently and asynchronously—an essential pattern for building scalable, loosely coupled microservices. As you modernize your integration landscape and move toward more reactive architectures, consider evolving from queue-based patterns to topic-driven messaging to fully embrace the benefits of event-driven architecture.

entry.title: Re: KO88 doesn't settle down payment to ASSET UNDER CONST...
entry.content: Hello, thanks for your reply.I was able to resolve the issue temporarily by manually entering the internal order when posting the down payment in F-47. With this workaround, KO88 does consider the down payment. However, this is not the expected behavior — KO88 should automatically take the down payment based on the purchase order, without the need for manual entry. I tested the process in our sand box test environment and it worked correctly there (no need to manually specify the internal order), but in the quality environment it does not work and still requires manual input.
